stories.title: Abandoned Railways: Saluda Grade – North America's Steepest Mainline [1:00:48]

stories.text:
Hello HN, I am envisioning a webapp with the least amount of friction to enroll a user. Is using a TOTP based authentication with no password a safe technique or does it have some glaring holes that I am missing.

Example - user enters an email and receives a TOTP based 8 digit code valid for the next 10 minutes. The user enters the code and is able to view the authenticated information.
stories.title: Ask HN: Is using just a TOTP based authenticatation safe or a privacy issue
Intel’s Arctic Sound-M to Land Mid-2022 with Hardware AV1 Encoding
“Can it run Doom” will never be the same, thanks to new ray-tracing mod

stories.text:
So, I am currently looking for a tool that allows me to do literate programming.

My goal is to create a pen and paper RPG, kinda like D&D, but simpler. I'd like to develop a Python module along with it which allows me to test and balance the mechanics of the game -- maybe even use it during play sessions to keep track of data. I want to try the literate programming approach here, writing down the rules of the game along with creating the module.

While I'll be using Python as programming language, I'd rather avoid anything notebook related. I just don't like the concept of notebooks and would rather create a typical module, that can also be viewed/rendered as HTML. Would be great if the tool is language agnostic though.

Markdown, AsciiDoc, or reStructuredText are okay. I know org-mode is a common recommendation, but I am not an Emacs guy and org-mode support isn't that great in other editors.

Typesetting equations using LaTeX syntax is a bonus, but certainly not required. LaTeX as output format is not required at all.
stories.title: Ask HN: Literate Programming Tool Recommendation
Ex-Russian oligarch says one moment in war drove Putin ‘insane’
The Most Important Performance Management Rule for Software Engineers

stories.text:
Howdy HN,

I have a few ideas I’m considering hiring contractors to bootstrap, however I need help on how to protect myself, my ideas, and code from the contractors I hire. I know I can hire an attorney, but I was wondering if there are any resources around common contracts to use as a starting point?

Thanks!
stories.title: Ask HN: Resources for Contractor Contracts?
